text: I'm Anthony Thomasina from the New York
Times and I want to talk about five
moments and five pieces that really just
get to me the idea is that in classical
pieces sometimes a composer almost
self-consciously you can hear him saying
I'm gonna get you I'm gonna really grab
you and it's not necessarily the
fanciest or most complicated thing but
there's something about I've got my
personal moments and I want to share
some of them with you and see if I could
explain why they get to
when I was 12 years old and studying
piano I bought an LP of Archer
Rubinstein playing the for Chopin
ballads and I remember going to the
basement and putting it on and it was I
was not sixty seconds into the first
Balad where I was completely just hooked
by it but especially this very intensely
quiet harmonic thing that happens that
begins like this now all that's doing
really is outlining kind of tracing this
chord that has a very fancy name the
Neapolitan six chord but it's just this
chord that leads to this one and then to
the key and the piece G minor but kind
of loses its way very quizzical then
comes this moment now what is it
now if you take out the cord I think
what the no idea swats to do go to the
key of the piece but Chopin kind of
warns you with this harmony it's that's
if he ain't seeing he's warning you this
piece is going to get very heavy going
this is going to be very tumultuous very
intense very sad now are you sure you
want to go forward with this it's not
too late to back out but you want to do
it you're gonna do it okay so let's go
now this theme is very mournful but does
it sound
tumultuous and that happens later so
this is one of my favorite moments but
I'd like to hear from you please send me
your favorite moods
I'll respond to comments and I'm gonna
put together another video with some of
your choices
